msDesc.physDesc: The letter is one page long on cream colored paper with typewritten text. At the top of the first page there is an indecipherable, paranthetical word written in pencil.

body.div:
February 28, 1916 My dear Mrs. Aldis:
Your play has safely arrived, but I have not had time to read it yet. I shall do so, however, as soon as possible, and I feel sure that I have a rare treat in front of me.
I was on the point of sending you “The Grocery Shop”, and I am very glad that you found it. I will bring a copy of “Off The Turnpike” with me when I come to Chicago.
I am delighted to hear that Mr. and Mrs. Masters will be at your house at lunch—and Mr. Ficke, too. I cannot think of anybody else whom I should like to meet,—I am sure that anybody you invite will be most agreeable to me, or nobody more than you’ve got. It seems to me a charming party as it is.
I am particularly glad that your paper on Imagism went well. Feeling does run rather high, but I think, on the whole, it is a good thing.
I will write you again more fully when I have read your play. In the meanwhile, Very sincerely yours,

div.note: Helen Jenkins was the wife of Edgar Lee Masters from 1898-1923. At the time this letter was written, Lowell would have been referring to Helen Jenkins when referencing Mrs. Masters.
